question.title: Why cannot run() of Runnable throw checked Exceptions?

node.contents: According to section 6.3.2 of JCIP :

node.contents: Runnable is a fairly limiting abstraction; run can not return a value or throw checked exception .

astNode.text: Runnable is a fairly limiting abstraction; run can not return a value or throw checked exception .

node.contents: run() can not return a value since its return type is void but why can not it throw a checked exception ?

astNode.text: run() can not return a value since its return type is void but why can not it throw a checked exception ?

node.contents: You don't even need to use `Unsafe`. Checked exceptions thrown from a no-args constructor escape a `newInstance` call. I'll add an answer ...

node.contents: You can always unsafely throw checked exceptions:

astNode.text: You can always unsafely throw checked exceptions:

elements.contents: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class UnsafeSample { public void methodWithNoDeclaredExceptions( ) { Unsafe unsafe = getUnsafe(); unsafe.throwException( new Exception( "this should be checked" ) ); } private Unsafe getUnsafe() { try { Field field = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe) field.get(null); } catch(Exception e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } } public static void main( String[] args ) { new UnsafeSample().methodWithNoDeclaredExceptions(); } }

units.rawText: import java.lang.reflect.Field; import sun.misc.Unsafe; public class UnsafeSample { public void methodWithNoDeclaredExceptions( ) { Unsafe unsafe = getUnsafe(); unsafe.throwException( new Exception( "this should be checked") ); } private Unsafe getUnsafe() { try { Field field = Unsafe.class.getDeclaredField("theUnsafe"); field.setAccessible(true); return (Unsafe) field.get(null); } catch(Exception e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } } public static void main( String[] args ) { new UnsafeSample().methodWithNoDeclaredExceptions(); } }

node.contents: This is not an answer to the question. Rather, it is a followup to Lukas Eder's answer, showing another way to smuggle a checked exception into a place where it is not statically allowed. This relies on the fact that if a no-argument constructor is invoked with newInstance, any checked exception it throws escapes upward.

astNode.text: This is not an answer to the question. Rather, it is a followup to Lukas Eder's answer, showing another way to smuggle a checked exception into a place where it is not statically allowed. This relies on the fact that if a no-argument constructor is invoked with newInstance, any checked exception it throws escapes upward.

elements.contents: public class Thrower { private static final ThreadLocal<Exception> toThrow = new ThreadLocal<Exception>(); public static void throwUnsafely(Exception e) { try { toThrow.set(e); Thrower.class.newInstance(); } catch (InstantiationException f) { throw new RuntimeException("unexpected exception while throwing expected exception", f); } catch (IllegalAccessException f) { throw new RuntimeException("unexpected exception while throwing expected exception", f); } finally { toThrow.remove(); } } private Thrower() throws Exception { throw toThrow.get(); } }

units.rawText: public class Thrower { private static final ThreadLocal<Exception> toThrow = new ThreadLocal<Exception>(); public static void throwUnsafely(Exception e) { try { toThrow.set(e); Thrower.class.newInstance(); } catch (InstantiationException f) { throw new RuntimeException("unexpected exception while throwing expected exception", f); } catch (IllegalAccessException f) { throw new RuntimeException("unexpected exception while throwing expected exception", f); } finally { toThrow.remove(); } } private Thrower() throws Exception { throw toThrow.get(); } }

node.contents:
@peter Callable
<void>
  only says the return from the call is of type void ? Does it say anything at all for exceptions that can be thrown from call ()?
</void>

astNode.text:
@peter Callable
<void>
  only says the return from the call is of type void ? Does it say anything at all for exceptions that can be thrown from call ()?
</void>

node.contents: The fact that there is no `throws` clause states there are no check exceptions. Even if the parent declares `throws Exception` doesn't mean the child has to. However if the parent does not "throws" a checked exception, the child cannot throw a checked exception.

astNode.text: The fact that there is no `throws` clause states there are no check exceptions. Even if the parent declares `throws Exception` doesn't mean the child has to. However if the parent does not "throws" a checked exception, the child cannot throw a checked exception.

node.contents: Hey Peter Thanks for the good reply ! request you please elaborate on this "Originally Runnable was only used in a wrapped Thread, and it was assumed the developer would want to catch all checked exceptions and handle them rather than logging them to System.err."

astNode.text: Hey Peter Thanks for the good reply ! request you please elaborate on this "Originally Runnable was only used in a wrapped Thread, and it was assumed the developer would want to catch all checked exceptions and handle them rather than logging them to System.err."

node.contents: @Naroji Runnable isn't designed to throw checked exceptions, but Callable is.

astNode.text: @Naroji Runnable isn't designed to throw checked exceptions, but Callable is.

node.contents: @PeterLawrey thanks , I agree with your point. but what I am looking is the thought process behind it (reason why these are designed like this)

astNode.text: @PeterLawrey thanks , I agree with your point. but what I am looking is the thought process behind it (reason why these are designed like this)

node.contents: @Naroji Checked exception are intended to be handled by the caller. For Runnable in Java 1.0, there was no common way to handle exception thrown out of run(). In Java 5.0, there is a way to submit a task and have it throw a checked exception, and you to handle it when you `get()` the result.

astNode.text: @Naroji Checked exception are intended to be handled by the caller. For Runnable in Java 1.0, there was no common way to handle exception thrown out of run(). In Java 5.0, there is a way to submit a task and have it throw a checked exception, and you to handle it when you `get()` the result.

node.contents: It cannot throw a checked exception because it wasn't declared as throwing a checked exception from the first version and it is too dangerous to change it.

astNode.text: It cannot throw a checked exception because it wasn't declared as throwing a checked exception from the first version and it is too dangerous to change it.

node.contents: Originally Runnable was only used in a wrapped Thread, and it was assumed the developer would want to catch all checked exceptions and handle them rather than logging them to System.err.

astNode.text: Originally Runnable was only used in a wrapped Thread, and it was assumed the developer would want to catch all checked exceptions and handle them rather than logging them to System.err.

node.contents: Callable was added when you can add individual tasks to an Executor where you can capture the result in a Future and any exception thrown.

astNode.text: Callable was added when you can add individual tasks to an Executor where you can capture the result in a Future and any exception thrown.

node.contents: Callable now allows you to return a value and optional declare a checked exception.

astNode.text: Callable now allows you to return a value and optional declare a checked exception.

node.contents: BTW: One way you can say you don't want a return or throw a checked exception from a callable is to use something like

astNode.text: BTW: One way you can say you don't want a return or throw a checked exception from a callable is to use something like

elements.contents: Callable<Void> callable = new Callable<Void>() { public Void call() { // do something return null; } };

node.contents: Precisely. As others said, it is obvious that the literal answer is "run() is not declared to throw anything," but I think the real question is why it is so. And the answer is, run() is meant to be called by a thread, which terminates or returns to a pool after run() returns, so who would catch it? Therefore there is never a case where throwing an exception would be useful.

astNode.text: Precisely. As others said, it is obvious that the literal answer is "run() is not declared to throw anything," but I think the real question is why it is so. And the answer is, run() is meant to be called by a thread, which terminates or returns to a pool after run() returns, so who would catch it? Therefore there is never a case where throwing an exception would be useful.

node.contents: I think the motivation behind keeping the signature void run() in Runnable is that it is not meant to be invoked like other methods, instead it is designed to be invoked by the CPU thread scheduler. If so, who is going to receive its return value and who is going to handle thrown checked exception by this. UncaughtExceptionHandler came in Java 5.0 to handle uncaught exceptions thrown by a Thread. The Executor Framework saves the returned value or thrown exception( wrapper in ExecutionException) as the states of some Object shared across threads(like Outer class instance) and purveys those to the invoker(who is running in some other thread) of Future.get().

astNode.text: I think the motivation behind keeping the signature void run() in Runnable is that it is not meant to be invoked like other methods, instead it is designed to be invoked by the CPU thread scheduler. If so, who is going to receive its return value and who is going to handle thrown checked exception by this. UncaughtExceptionHandler came in Java 5.0 to handle uncaught exceptions thrown by a Thread. The Executor Framework saves the returned value or thrown exception( wrapper in ExecutionException) as the states of some Object shared across threads(like Outer class instance) and purveys those to the invoker(who is running in some other thread) of Future.get().

node.contents: If you look at the Runnable Interface you find that void run() method is not declared as throwing any checked exception and your Thread class implements Runnable Interface .

astNode.text: If you look at the Runnable Interface you find that void run() method is not declared as throwing any checked exception and your Thread class implements Runnable Interface .

node.contents: JLS says that method m1 cannot throw exception if in Interface/Superclass it is not declared.

astNode.text: JLS says that method m1 cannot throw exception if in Interface/Superclass it is not declared.

node.contents: What's especially confusing is that current docs for [invokeAndWait](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/javax/swing/SwingUtilities.html#invokeAndWait%28java.lang.Runnable%29) discuss what happens "if the Runnable.run method throws an uncaught exception". I'm sure many people have read that and blithely tried to declare an exceptions clause for their overriding run()s.

astNode.text: What's especially confusing is that current docs for [invokeAndWait](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/javax/swing/SwingUtilities.html#invokeAndWait%28java.lang.Runnable%29) discuss what happens "if the Runnable.run method throws an uncaught exception". I'm sure many people have read that and blithely tried to declare an exceptions clause for their overriding run()s.

node.contents: run() can't throw a checked exception because it is not declared to do so. You can't throw checked exceptions without declaring them.

astNode.text: run() can't throw a checked exception because it is not declared to do so. You can't throw checked exceptions without declaring them.

node.contents: You also can't declare checked exceptions on a method which overrides or implements another method which doesn't throw that exception. So, implementations of Runnable can't simply add throws clauses to their implementations of run().

astNode.text: You also can't declare checked exceptions on a method which overrides or implements another method which doesn't throw that exception. So, implementations of Runnable can't simply add throws clauses to their implementations of run().
